raw.author: Immanuel Kant
contexts: modern political philosophers—from Immanuel Kant in the eighteenth century to John Rawls in the twentieth century—argue that the principles of justice that define our rights should not rest on any particular conception of virtue, or of the best way to live.
Aristotle, Immanuel Kant, John Stuart Mill, and John Rawls all figure in these pages.
The greatest defender of this approach is Immanuel Kant, to whom we turn in the next chapter.
Kant’s Case for Rights Immanuel Kant (1724–1804) offers an alternative account of duties and rights, one of the most powerful and influential accounts any philosopher has produced.
Immanuel Kant offered a more powerful version of the choosing self.

Kant writes of “the confusion of the philosophers concerning the supreme principle of morals.” The ancient philosophers made the mistake of “devoting their ethical investigations entirely to the definition of the concept of the highest good,” and then trying to make this good “the determining ground of the moral law.”

Immanuel Kant, “Duties Toward the Body in Respect of Sexual Impulse” (1784–85), translated by Louis Infield and published in Immanuel Kant, Lectures on Ethics (Cambridge, Mass.
: Hackettt Publishing, 1981), p. 164.

This line of reasoning leads Kant to the second formulation of the categorical imperative: “Act in such a way that you always treat humanity, whether in your own person or in the person of any other, never simply as a means, but always at the same time as an end.”23
But as Kant reminds us, a person is not a thing, “not something to be used merely as a means.”
But any principle based on interest “was bound to be always a conditioned one and could not possibly serve as a moral law.”25
Kant’s categorical imperative tells us to treat everyone with respect, as an end in itself.
Kant seems to suggest that answering to duty and acting autonomously are one and the same.
Kant seems to think that we will all agree on the same moral law.
Kant argues that if morality is more than a matter of prudential calculation, it must take the form of a categorical imperative.
Kant says we can’t help but understand ourselves from both standpoints—the empirical realm of physics and biology, and an “intelligible” realm of free human agency.

Kant argues that only from this second (intelligible) standpoint can I regard myself as free, “for to be independent of determination by causes in the sensible world (and this is what reason must always attribute to itself) is to be free.”29
“When we think of ourselves as free, we transfer ourselves into the intelligible world as members and recognize the autonomy of the will together with its consequence—morality.”30
“To argue freedom away,” Kant writes, “is as impossible for the most abstruse philosophy as it is for the most ordinary human reason.”33
Kant considered this practice a violation of human dignity.
supports the Kantian thought that there is a morally relevant difference between a lie and a misleading truth.
And on Kant’s moral theory, it’s the intention, or motive, that matters.

Kant’s point is not that this state of affairs, in which people parse politicians’ denials for their literal meaning, is somehow better than one in which nobody believes politicians at all. That would be a consequentialist argument. Kant’s point is rather that a misleading statement that is nonetheless true does not coerce or manipulate the listener in the same way as an outright lie.

So there is reason to conclude that, on Kant’s moral theory, true but misleading statements—to a murderer at the door, the Prussian censors, or the special prosecutor—are morally permissible in a way that bald-faced lies are not.

You may think that I’ve worked too hard to save Kant from an implausible position. Kant’s claim that it’s wrong to lie to the murderer at the door may not ultimately be defensible. But the distinction between an outright lie and a misleading truth helps illustrate Kant’s moral theory.
Kant and justice Unlike Aristotle, Bentham, and Mill, Kant wrote no major work of political theory, only some essays.
Liberal theories of justice, from Kant to Rawls, worry that teleological conceptions are at odds with freedom.
Kant and Rawls reject Aristotle’s teleology because it doesn’t seem to leave us room to choose our good for ourselves.

raw.author: John Rawls
contexts: modern political philosophers—from Immanuel Kant in the eighteenth century to John Rawls in the twentieth century—argue that the principles of justice that define our rights should not rest on any particular conception of virtue, or of the best way to live.
Aristotle, Immanuel Kant, John Stuart Mill, and John Rawls all figure in these pages.
We’ll be better equipped to assess this debate when we turn to the political philosophy of John Rawls—a member of the freedom camp who rejects the libertarian account of justice.
In the twentieth century, John Rawls adapted Kant’s conception of the autonomous self and drew upon it in his theory of justice.
John Rawls also defends redistribution, but on the grounds of hypothetical consent.
This is Rawls’s idea of the social contract—a hypothetical agreement in an original position of equality.
If you can imagine a contract like this, you have arrived at Rawls’s idea of a hypothetical agreement in an initial situation of equality.
According to Rawls, we wouldn’t choose utilitarianism.
we would adopt what Rawls calls “the difference principle”
Rawls’s theory is not meant to assess the fairness of this or that person’s salary; it is concerned with the basic structure of society
Rawls doesn’t believe that people choosing principles to govern their fundamental life prospects would take such chances.
Rawls presents this argument by comparing several rival theories of justice, beginning with feudal aristocracy.
These systems are unfair, Rawls observes, because they distribute income, wealth, opportunity, and power according to the accident of birth.
That is why, Rawls argues, the distribution of income and wealth that results from a free market with formal equality of opportunity cannot be considered just.
Rawls’s reply is that the difference principle permits income inequalities for the sake of incentives, provided the incentives are needed to improve the lot of the least advantaged.
Rawls rejects the meritocratic theory of justice on the grounds that people’s natural talents are not their own doing.
Rawls replies that even effort may be the product of a favorable upbringing.
If Rawls’s argument about the moral arbitrariness of talents is right, it leads to a surprising conclusion: Distributive justice is not a matter of rewarding moral desert.
Dworkin’s account of justice in university admissions runs parallel to Rawls’s account of justice in income distribution: It is not a matter of moral desert.
Because, following Rawls’s point about moral desert, no one deserves to be considered for an apartment or a seat in the freshman class according to his or her merits, independently defined.
As Rawls reminds us, “no one deserves his greater natural capacity nor merits a more favorable starting place in society.”
Liberal theories of justice, from Kant to Rawls, worry that teleological conceptions are at odds with freedom.
For Rawls, the arrangement would be just only if the free exchange of labor took place against fair background conditions.
Rawls makes a similar point with respect to principles of justice: “The liberties of equal citizenship are insecure when founded upon teleological principles.”
As Rawls writes, “it is not clear what is the requisite binding action or who has performed it.”44
For Kant and Rawls, the right is prior to the good.

raw.author: Aristotle
contexts: Aristotle teaches that justice means giving people what they deserve.
But arguments about the rights and wrongs of economic arrangements often lead us back to Aristotle’s question of what people morally deserve, and why.
It goes back to the dialogues of Socrates and the moral philosophy of Aristotle.
Aristotle, Immanuel Kant, John Stuart Mill, and John Rawls all figure in these pages.
The notion that we identify the norms appropriate to social practices by trying to grasp the characteristic end, or purpose, of those practices is at the heart of Aristotle’s theory of justice.
As we will see when we turn to Aristotle (in Chapter 8), the virtue-based approach connects justice to reflection about the good life.
Kant and justice Unlike Aristotle, Bentham, and Mill, Kant wrote no major work of political theory, only some essays.
Justice, Telos, and Honor Seen in this way, the dustup over cheerleaders in West Texas is a short course in Aristotle’s theory of justice.

Central to Aristotle’s political philosophy are two ideas, both present in the argument over Callie: 1. Justice is teleological. Defining rights requires us to figure out the telos (the purpose, end, or essential nature) of the social practice in question. 2. Justice is honorific. To reason about the telos of a practice—or to argue about it—is, at least in part, to reason or argue about what virtues it should honor and reward. The key to understanding Aristotle’s ethics and politics is to see the force of these two considerations, and the relation between them.
Plato and Aristotle thought that fire rose because it was reaching for the sky, its natural home, and that stones fell because they were striving to get closer to the earth, where they belonged.
Today, no scientist reads Aristotle’s works on biology or physics and takes them seriously. But students of ethics and politics continue to read and ponder Aristotle’s moral and political philosophy.
The debate over affirmative action can be recast in terms that echo Aristotle’s account of flutes.

That arguments about universities—and cheerleaders and flutes—naturally proceed in this way bears out Aristotle’s point: Arguments about justice and rights are often arguments about the purpose, or telos, of a social institution, which in turn reflect competing notions of the virtues the institution should honor and reward.
Aristotle believes that it is possible to reason about the purpose of social institutions.
Aristotle offers his most sustained answer to these questions in his discussion of politics.
But Aristotle reminds us that all theories of distributive justice discriminate.

Aristotle doesn’t see it this way. For Aristotle, the purpose of politics is not to set up a framework of rights that is neutral among ends. It is to form good citizens and to cultivate good character.
Aristotle criticizes what he takes to be the two major claimants to political authority—oligarchs and democrats.
For Aristotle, politics is about something higher. It’s about learning how to live a good life.
Aristotle writes
For Aristotle, this is the primary purpose of law—to cultivate the habits that lead to good character.
According to Aristotle, their natures did not suit them to be citizens.
For Aristotle, coercion is a sign of injustice, not because consent legitimates all roles, but because the need for force suggests an unnatural fit.
the federal case over Casey Martin’s cart offers a vivid illustration of Aristotle’s theory of justice.
For Aristotle, the purpose of politics is not only to ease economic exchange and provide for the common defense; it is also to cultivate good character and form good citizens.
“Before we can [investigate] the nature of an ideal constitution,” Aristotle wrote, “it is necessary for us first to determine the nature of the most desirable way of life.
If the right is prior to the good, then Aristotle’s way of thinking about justice is also mistaken.
For MacIntyre (as for Aristotle), the narrative, or teleological, aspect of moral reflection is bound up with membership and belonging.
This way of thinking about justice is at odds with Aristotle’s way.
And, as Aristotle reminds us, to argue about the purpose of a social institution is to argue about the virtues it honors and rewards.
In Aristotle’s terms, the issue is the just distribution of offices and honors.
Aristotle’s view

contexts: According to Nozick, the moral stakes go beyond money.
He reasons as follows: “Taxation of earnings from labor is on a par with forced labor.”10
This . . . makes them a part-owner of you; it gives them a property right in you.11
That is why, according to Nozick, taxing some of Michael Jordan’s $31 million to help the poor violates his rights.
But Nozick maintains that it does claim to own part of us—whatever part corresponds to the portion of income we must pay to support causes beyond the minimal state.
As Nozick writes, “The central core of the notion of a property right in X . . . is the right to determine what shall be done with X.”12

contexts: One of the most famous statements of the civic case for conscription was offered by Jean-Jacques Rousseau (1712–1778), the Geneva-born Enlightenment political theorist. In The Social Contract (1762), he argues that turning a civic duty into a marketable good does not increase freedom, but rather undermines it: As soon as public service ceases to be the chief business of the citizens, and they would rather serve with their money than with their persons, the state is not far from its fall. When it is necessary to march out to war, they pay troops and stay at home.
Jean-Jacques Rousseau, The Social Contract (1762), Book III, chap.

goodreads_match.title: AWOL: The Unexcused Absence of America's Upper Classes from Military Service -- and How It Hurts Our Country
goodreads_match.description:
Military service was once taken for granted as a natural part of good citizenship, and Americans of all classes served during wartime.
Not anymore.
As Kathy Roth-Douquet and Frank Schaeffer assert in this groundbreaking work, there is a glaring disconnect between the "all volunteer military" and the rest of us. And as that gap between the cultural "elite" and military rank-and-file widens, our country faces a dangerous lack of understanding between those in power and those who defend our way of life.
